page.title: 09GRIMSBY FISHING INDUSTRY
page.content: There has been a remarkable{decline}in the Grimsby{fishing industry}in recent years.The large{freezer trawlers}and conventional distant water trawlers- fishing as far afield as the{White Sea and the{Newfoundland Banks}-have long ceased to operate.The last of the middle water trawlers is now bein converted to an{oil rig}support vessel.Fishing is now carried out in the{North Sea}by{Seine netters}and other small boats.The variety of fish available on the market is still wide at times,including cod,haddock, plaice, sole and less important varieties such as halibut and monk.The amount landed by Grimsby boats is limited;the{fish market}is often boosted by{supplies brought overland from Aberdeen and Peterhead and by varying amounts from Iceland,the Faroes and the Netherlands.
